awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Interrogating Negative Thermal Expansion in Earth-Abundant Oxide Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Non-Technical Summary
Thermal expansion, the way materials change shape when you heat or cool them, is an important property to be able to understand and control. Many objects that people rely on every day (i.e. building materials, aerospace parts, etc.) can wear out or fail more easily if their thermal expansion is not matched well, thus creating more waste and higher costs in the world. While many materials expand as you heat them, some materials shrink as you heat them and are important to study. Therefore, it is important to understand how to control these properties so that new types of materials can be engineered. With this LEAPS-MPS project, Professor Joya Cooley at California State University, Fullerton, will focus on understanding why certain classes of materials which consist of earth-abundant elements shrink instead of expanding upon heating.  The research is conducted at a primarily undergraduate institution where undergraduate students will be trained in a variety of synthetic and characterization techniques. Specifically, students from historically underserved backgrounds will be recruited to work on this project and will disseminate findings to the public through local outreach, allowing participating students to serve as role models for future scientists from historically underserved backgrounds. Furthermore, this local outreach will work to increase the amount of citizen science, public scientific literacy, and overall public interest in materials chemistry.


Technical Summary
This LEAPS-MPS award is aimed at understanding structural and chemical driving forces that lead to technologically relevant negative thermal expansion (NTE) in materials. This work will interrogate local and long-range structure in materials crystallizing as metal pyrophosphates and pyrovanadates (A2B2O7) using inexpensive and readily accessible elements (e.g., A = Mg, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu; B = P, V). The goal is to achieve the following: (1) investigate the role of A and B site elements and their influence on parent crystal structure; (2) understand the role of A and B site elements and their role in tuning temperature and range of NTE. The ability to vary metal (A) and nonmetal (B) identities in pyrophosphate (A2P2O7) and pyrovanadate (A2V2O7) materials by creating solid solutions provides a wealth of exploration possibilities for uncovering the structural drivers for NTE. By creating solid solutions between end members with properties at the extremes, this work will seek to elucidate the structural and chemical variables important to O motion that results in systematic control of NTE. This project will make use of (a) high resolution structural techniques, such as synchrotron diffraction; (a) techniques sensitive to light elements like O, such as neutron diffraction; (c) and techniques that provide a local understanding of atom motion, such as temperature dependent microscopy. Undergraduate students will be trained in solid-state chemistry techniques, including the opportunities to work with national laboratories for remote or hands-on experiments. Historically underserved students will be recruited to be part of this project and will engage in local outreach to increase public scientific interest and literacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Controlling how dimensions change with temperature is an important aspect of material design and development. Materials exhibiting negative thermal expansion contract when heated and, when precisely controlled, can provide tunability of bulk materials’ thermal expansion. This project explored using chemical composition to tune thermal expansion through research at a primarily undergraduate Hispanic Serving Institution.

Overview and Intellectual Merit: This proposal provided funding for efforts to research and understand how to control thermal expansion using materials based on inexpensive transition metal oxides. Structures in the A2Q2O7 family (A = divalent metal, Q = P5+ or V5+) were identified as having traits which could exhibit negative thermal expansion, and these structures were subjected to small changes in chemical composition so that changes in thermal expansion properties could be correlated to changes in structure. These crystal structures are framework oxide materials, meaning they are made of interconnecting transition metal centered-polyhedra, which are flexible and often display negative thermal expansion. Solid solutions of these materials were synthesized with varying compositions as powders via solid state ceramic synthesis and sol-gel synthetic methods. Phase identification, purity, and structural parameters were determined using in-house powder X-ray diffraction and synchrotron X-ray diffraction obtained through national laboratory mail-in data collection programs. Some of the key accomplishments include elucidating how to control thermal expansion using chemical substitution in Zn2V2O7, specifically by affecting the flexibility of the Zn-O3-V bond which is partly responsible for the mechanism, an understanding of how to control the temperature at which there is a structural phase transition, and elucidating the discrepancies in thermal expansion properties across length scales in these materials.

Broader Impacts: This project provided students at a primarily undergraduate Hispanic Serving Institution to engage in experiential learning through meaningful research experiences. Over the project period of three years, undergraduate and Master’s students were trained in synthetic methods, characterization, and data analysis to lead their research projects. The students prepared and presented research posters and oral presentations at local, national, and international scientific conferences. Students were also invited to share their research with peers at California State University, Fullerton as their data and conclusions were regularly incorporated into lecture material for students in lower- and upper-division chemistry courses. Undergraduate authors are co-authors on peer-reviewed research as a result of this work. This project provided unique opportunities for students to develop their scientific skills and identities at a crucial point in their scientific careers. Students not only participate in hands-on research, such as the unique experience of conducting research at a national laboratory, but also take ownership of their projects by solving multifaceted problems and using the scientific method to approach complex questions. This project allowed students to develop their social and scientific communication skills and to serve as role models for future scientists.
